RRIfYesStrongerCandidate77: I believe I am a better candidate because of my experience and understanding since I applied last. This subject area is a better fit for me and something I feel passionate about. This year I reviewed application information more closely and looked at what the qualities the NYCTF selection committee is looking for. On this application, I feel clearer and more confident in the subject area I am pursuing and the answers to my questions. I believe I have learned from my last application how to be a better candidate.

When I first applied to the Fellows Program, I was doing it as one of many projects to get more teaching experience. I had spent two years abroad teaching, and while this had shown me how to run a basic ESL class, I still had no idea why I wanted to teach or who I wanted to teach. I didn't even know which country I wanted to live in. Now I have invested 3 years in ESL teaching in American cities. I moved to New York largely with the idea of teaching ESL to underprivileged foreign communities, for whom I felt it could be of more instantly practical benefit. My experiences with this have not disappointed; in fact they have given me a desire to connect to this city and its inhabitants through teaching. 
My desire and sense of purpose have become much clearer and stronger. I have also gained a lot of experience teaching. I am still at the beginning of my career, but since coming back to America 3 years ago, I have taught at 5 different schools. All of these schools expected teachers to be inspiring enough to retain students, who paid weekly or monthly. I feel that this has taught me to always provide a valuable teaching product, and molded me firmly in the student-centered class model. I have always had to balance fun and constructive learning, and if my students didn't like it, they could quit, but they never did. 
Middle and high school classes can be dreary, intimidating places. ESL students in particular can feel judged for their abilities and sometimes respond by resisting all forms of education. I have consistently proven that I can create fun, nurturing atmospheres where students are happy and eager to contribute. I have also consistently proven that I can help students evolve their language quickly and naturally. I want to put this experience to use in a public school setting.

What has motivated me to reapply is the desire to not give up and I truly believe that I can make a difference. I believe that I am a stronger candidate now because I’ve had to the time and opportunity to enhance my skills. Prior experience had help increase my level of patience as well as help hone my passion. I also believe that I possess a unique set of skill in regards to dealing with children in both the low income communities and especially with special needs. I believe that my mindset coupled with my experience will make have made me one of the best candidates for this programs as well as to be a teacher.

The leaders were many years younger than I, but they made our experience relaxed and rewarding. That night convinced me that the NYC fellowship program was for me. I feel very strongly that this program will help me become an effective educator who can help children achieve their potential.

Hello Ms. Aguilar,

I hope you are doing well and enjoyed your Thanksgiving. I am writing with regards to the notification I received today that my status in Teaching Fellows is pending a review by the NYC OEO. I have discussed this matter with Mrs. Ackert and believe she is contacting you as well.

I would like to first extend my deepest apologies for any comments I made that were perceived as biased, prejudiced, or unfair. I have never intended to engage in language that is offensive based on race or any other characteristic. I realize that discussions about these topics—particularly during this contentious election season—can often be fraught and I apologize if something I said caused unnecessary tension. It was not my goal and does not reflect my deeply-held belief in the equality of all people. I reject the divisive rhetoric and beliefs that have been so widespread during this election and made a point to repeatedly emphasize the value of inclusion, diversity, and tolerance to my students at Inwood 52. I will continue to expand my understanding of race-related topics in order to reduce any latent bias I have and ensure I engage in these matters professionally, respectfully, and sensitively.

My goal has always been to further interracial understanding and cooperation. I care about our students and colleagues from all racial, ethnic, and national backgrounds and will do my best to demonstrate that in my work.

I would appreciate your input on how I should proceed with my new job. My new school has had a vacancy for their 6th grade ICT position since September, which has meant that students have gone without a second teacher and have thus lacked individualized attention and mentoring. This is particularly unacceptable for the students with special needs, who legally and ethically deserve a teacher who can provide high-quality, differentiated instruction. My goal is to provide that as soon as possible. My new school has already nominated me for this position and I have completed the requisite verification with DoE HR; I am fully prepared to step into this role.

I am more than happy to proceed with this position while the review is underway, of course with the understanding that we will have to assess the results of the review at that future date (be it a few days or a few weeks from now). My interest is in serving these students any way that I can. I very much hope to do so.

Please let me know how you expect I proceed at your earliest convenience.

Thank you,
Casey Penk

RRIssueLogBody5106:
Fellow's documentation of his tenure at 29Q015 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

                                                        PS15
Days of 12/15 - 12/26 Issue with me working out of license/1st meetings with the AP about the curriculum
• I jumped through a lot of hoops to work in this class. First, I was working out of license as this was a General Education classroom of 20 students. I talked to the Brooklyn College liaison who said that I could work out of license if I work in license the following year.
After a lot strings being pulled I was approved to work in this particular class even though I am currently out of license.
• Mrs. Holstein gives me a quick tutorial on Think Central, gives me a password, username and then tells me to figure it out. This is the 1st year the school is using this program yet I must figure it out in less than 2.5 weeks. Also, the lesson planning template is a how to put a book in a bin lesson plan.   
• A very quick tutorial on Think Central along with logon information was given, then I was assumed to learn the program (without assistance) by my ‘start date’. Even though this program is new to all teachers/administration. Also, the lesson planning template is a how to put a book in a bin lesson plan.   

4th Day Jan. 6th  

   

1st Day Jan.3rd 
• The day before I spoke to the AP and she assured me the I would be eased into the classroom. The ATR would stay with me for an unspecified time, so I could get the gist of the classroom dynamics/environment. This did not happen.
• Tuesday the 3rd, I get to the school early and speak with Ms. Leary (The ATR) and tell her that I’ll be with her today. I had spent approximately 2 periods with the class and her that Thursday before the Christmas break. Prior to start time, the then she tells me, “I’m so sorry, I can’t believe they’re doing this to you, you’re on your own today.”
• I am told by the AP Ms. Holstein that I can’t introduce myself as the new teacher just yet, or call parents because Principal K’Tori is feeling you out right now.  
2nd Day Jan.4th 
• I’m gifted another student, a girl who has been getting homeschooled for the past month or so. I have at least 3 students who could use a one on one paraprofessional. Clearly, this class needs a para. Prior to me joining the class there were two teachers in the room together. I find that I am the 6th teacher since September, I was under the impression that I would be the 3rd. In fact, teachers in the building are telling me that I’m being set up to fail. 
• I find a problem with payroll as well. Apparently, I’m still registering as a paraprofessional. Per HR, I have 2 positions. 
3rd Day Jan. 5th 
• I learn that we’re to present a quick performance on College Readiness day during an assembly, which is scheduled for the 11th of January. 25 white tee shirts are purchased, and my wife & I decorate the shirts on the 10th of January until 1am. Winter intersession has just started at graduate school on the 3rd so I’m pretty much bombarded with getting the class together and my own schoolwork. I’m pretty much overwhelmed.
  4th Day Jan. 6th  
• The AP comes in and asks to see my lesson plan, 10 minutes before the end of the day. I inform them that I have it on electronic format. I’m then berated then told that I should always have to on paper. I was never informed of this unnecessary process. 
• I stay until 8:30 trying to clean and straighten up the room, which was left in such a state, I have to call my wife. 
• After getting home I think about all the things that I’ve been told by teachers and staff about the environment and administration at the school. I’m having a serious change of heart. From the “he listens in on you in the room by turning on the intercom in your room.”, to “He is the devil!”, to “I told you not to work here.”, I panic and on Sunday the 8th I then email the fellows to see if I can somehow get out of this situation. 

Week of Jan 9th – 13th 
• The fellows get back to me and tell me to wait it out and leave in June. Trying to be positive, I decide to stay; things can only get better.
• That Tuesday, my mom who has been holding from me her latest medical issue reveals to me that her doctor told her that she may need surgery to alieve the chronic pain she suffers from due to her spinal stenosis and sciatica.
• That Wednesday, I met with the principal to discuss a possible release mainly due to the news of my mother’s problems. Extremely bothered and cold, he explained to me that I had to either resign or he would have to fire me or a final step that if I could find a principal willing to hire me he would transfer me to that principal. He seemed to think that I was quitting the DOE when in fact I explicitly told him I now need to be in a school close to her. He asked if I had already found a school and when I said no, he chastised me as being indecisive and that will be my downfall. After the bombardment of insults and condescension, he told me that I had to make this move asap. I explained to him that I can’t resign or get fired because I would be kicked out the teaching fellows program and that I’ll see if I can find a principal. I emailed a principal that I previously interviewed almost immediately and told him the situation. He had a position and he would love for me to work there. 
• Thursday the 12th, during the day, the principal tried calling Mr. K’tori that late afternoon, the was no answer and there was no option to leave a message. 
• Friday the 13th, there were many attempts to reach Mr. K’tori, left messages with Principal K’Tori’s secretary. Again, no answer, and no returned calls. 
• With 5 minutes remaining until the end of the day, I receive the attached letter. This was hand delivered by Ms. Ali (Secretary) and the AP. During my talk with Mr. K’Tori, never did I once say that I would resign. I did not even accept that as an option. The letter is filled with incorrect information. Thinking on our talk, I can only think that he intentionally lied to ruin my chance to become a teacher. I believe he is retaliating as I accused him of taking my request personally (which he did as he turned aggressive once he understood that I was requesting to transfer). His language in the letter is accusatory and belittling. His dismissive attitude toward my very short stay actually highlights how unprofessional he acts.
